page.title: 05Ecology in & around Northill
page.content: This area has a temperate climate. It is mainly arable farming land with areas of deciduous woodland which form important{wildlife habitats,}as do the ponds, moats & irrigation reservoirs. Although intensely farmed, there is a wide variety of wildlife including hares, rabbits, foxes, Muntjac deer, game birds, owls, snipe, nightingales, tree-creepers and woodpeckers. Bats nest in the Church & great crested newts, moorhens and ducks live on the ponds. To maintain an{ecological {balance}trees have been planted to re- place casualties of Dutch Elm disease. The burning in the fields of unwanted straw is lessening due to{government {regulations}and this should reduce possible damage to the environment. Public footpaths giving access to the fields and woodlands are being kept open by the local community.
